controller

Interface SubController

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractListSubController, AbstractPropertySubController, PropController

    public interface SubController
    Defines the uniform API for a "sub-controller" object. Sub-controllers are a modified hybrid of dispatchers from the Front Controller Pattern and basic Java EventListeners.

    The purpose of a sub-controller is to create a more highly cohesive control system for actionable logic in a program. When designing a sub-controller, programmers should group methods with related functionalities together into an implementation of this interface. This eliminates the clutter that can arise when a single controller object attempts to handle all actionable logic in a program.

    Sub-controllers are not meant to operate independently. They should be combined with a "master-controller" (ideally an implementation of the AbstractMasterController class). The relationship between sub-controllers and their master is simple: the master-controller is aware of all models, views, and other elements of the program. When events are fired in a view the master-controller is monitoring, it passes the event to its stored sub-controllers, along with data from the view which may be needed to perform any actions. This is done through the handleEvent() method. The sub-controller then inspects the event to determine if it is an event that it needs to respond to, and then passes the data (in the form of a Map parameter) to the appropriate method in the implementation.

    If an event is passed along that a sub-controller isn't prepared to handle, the appropriate response is to have nothing occur. Throwing an Exception is NOT recommended, as this would force the master controller to handle said Exception, thus reducing the abstraction of the system.

    For additional information on master-controllers and their relationship with sub-controllers, see the documentation for the AbstractMasterController class.
    Version:
    2.0
    Author:
    Craig

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void handleEvent(java.awt.event.ActionEvent event, java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> propertyValues)
      Handles an event fired off by a GUI view by taking action based on one or more of the values in the Map.

      Implementations of this interface should check the ActionEvent using conditional logic to confirm that it is meant for this particular sub-controller.

    • Method Detail

      • handleEvent

        void handleEvent(java.awt.event.ActionEvent event,
                 java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> propertyValues)
        Handles an event fired off by a GUI view by taking action based on one or more of the values in the Map.

        Implementations of this interface should check the ActionEvent using conditional logic to confirm that it is meant for this particular sub-controller. If it is, the Map parameter should be passed to an appropriate method in the implementation to handle the action.
        Parameters:
        event - the event that has occurred in a GUI view.
        propertyValues - a Map of all the propery values from the view that fired the event.
